situations.entry: Visit plant gates next week thanking workers for their support.
situations.name: work1a
situations.response: The plant gate idea was a cute plan, but workers wondered why a Republican was wasting his time.

situations.entry: Meet with influential lobbyists in Salt Lake City.
situations.name: work1b
situations.response: Lobbyists enjoyed your company.  Three lobbyists said their PACs could contribute $5,000 to your campaign.

situations.entry: Attend caucus retreat where you will discuss school reform issues including "No Child Left Behind" and "Teacher Tenure."
situations.name: work1c
situations.response: The caucus was packed.  It was good you were there.  Your passionate statements for school finance reform may have an effect.

situations.entry: Visit city halls introducing your constituent service plan.
situations.name: work1d
situations.response: City officials were astonished at your presence.  No Representative had visited a town hall meeting in years.  They appreciated it.

situations.entry: Conduct research on the bills you are going to introduce.
situations.name: work2a
situations.response: You spend an entire day in the state library.  You are now prepared to debate HB 240.

situations.entry: Attend a PTA meeting in Suburbia to discuss "No Child Left Behind."
situations.name: work2b
situations.response: Three hundred concerned parents were somewhat pleased you would meet with them.  The president of the school board told the press the future of the school was in your hands.

situations.entry: Pay attention to staff priorities and concerns.
situations.name: work2c
situations.response: Staff really needed the direction you gave them.  The office will run better now.

situations.entry: Visit Washington to discuss state budget problems with the congressional delegation.
situations.name: work2d
situations.response: Your visit went very well.  Senate Republican Leader Frist invited you for a picture opportunity.

situations.entry: Take your family on a short vacation.
situations.name: work3a
situations.response: The family had a great time in Bermuda.  The snorkeling was great, and your wife loved the time with you.

situations.entry: Meet with the governor to review the bills you have introduced.
situations.name: work3b
situations.response: The time spent on your legislation was well worth it.  They  will have a greater chance of avoiding a veto.

situations.entry: Send a questionnaire to your district
situations.name: work3c
situations.response: The questionnaire was loved by constituents.  More than 3,000 filled it out and mailed it in.

situations.entry: Meet with lobbyists interested in education issues.
situations.name: work3d
situations.response: The lobbyist meeting went well.  Their respect for you increases daily.

situations.entry: Meet with staff about their concerns.
situations.name: work4a
situations.response: Your staff appreciated your attention.  They will now stay with you through the election.

situations.entry: Organize a hearing at University of Disttrictville to discuss tuition levels.
situations.name: work4b
situations.response: Local constituents turned out "en mass" to tell you of their concerns.  A student suggested an idea for a bill to help economic development in the area.  It was a great evening.  You may have to hold more public forums.

situations.entry: Send a "franked" mail to your district.
situations.name: work4c
situations.response: Your constituents appreciated the mailing.  Local press criticized the fact that your picture appeared in the mailing ten times.  The Taxpayers United group filed a lawsuit asking you to repay the money spent on the mailing by the government.

situations.entry: Organize a fund-raiser.
situations.name: work4d
situations.response: A fund raiser was successful.  It raised $40,000, with most of it coming from political action Committees.

situations.entry: Organize your congressional campaign.
situations.name: work5a
situations.response: Your congressional campaign got off to a good start.  Forty people showed up to organize the campaign.  House Republicans are very upset.

situations.entry: Hold committee hearings throughout the state.
situations.name: work5b
situations.response: Thecommittee hearings in Murphy was sparsely attended.  You got three column inches in the newspaper saying the committee was there.  You were not mentioned.

situations.entry: Hold a fund-raiser.
situations.name: work5c
situations.response: The fund-raiser was a success.  An additional $30,000 was brought in.

situations.entry: Meet with constituents.
situations.name: work5d
situations.response: Your district townhall meetings were great.  Your idea of having two-way video from the high school to the middle school was featured in the newspaper.

situations.entry: Attend a Republican "get out the vote" rally on campus.
situations.name: work6a
situations.response: Students enjoy the rally with their representative.  Unfortunately, only 25 students showed up and they were already planning to vote for the Republican candidate from their home district.

situations.entry: Go door to door in swing precincts.
situations.name: work6b
situations.response: Door to door was very satisfying.  You received a good reception.  You were able to talk to 200 voters in the last few days.

situations.entry: Campaign with Governor Herbert in Republican neighborhoods.
situations.name: work6c
situations.response: People were impressed that the governor came to visit.  It seemed like they remembered him more than you.  You did gain some additional yard sign locations. Press wrote favorably about it.

situations.entry: Organize a fund-raiser for a last minute television blitz.
situations.name: work6d
situations.response: You received needed funds for the last-minute television blitz. It should help if you can get the ads produced in time.
